titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Cynthia Harrison feminist document collection, 1921-2008 MS1005.UA
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-11 11:32:59 -0500.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract:
This collection consists of articles, newsletters, children's books, lecture notes, personal notes, and personal correspondence, as well as photocopies of primary sources such as newspaper articles, press releases, reports and memoranda related to GWU Professor Cynthia Ellen Harrison's research and personal involvement in the women's rights movement. Items date from the early 1920's to the mid 1990's, with the bulk of the material dating to between 1960 and 1980.
Cynthia Ellen Harrison is a retired Associate Professor of History, Women's Studies, and Public Policy at The George Washington University. Since 1994 Professor Harrison served the University as a teacher and an active researcher in US women's political history.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of articles, newsletters, children's books, lecture notes, personal notes, and personal correspondence, as well as photocopies of primary sources such as newspaper articles, press releases, reports and memoranda related to GWU Professor Cynthia Ellen Harrison's research and personal involvement in the women's rights movement. Items date from the early 1920's to the mid 1990's, with the bulk of the material dating to between 1960 and 1980.

This collection was largely produced and/or used by Professor Harrison as part of her research for her 1988 book On Account of Sex: The Politics of Women's Issues, 1945-1968. Harrison created copies of original documents from various archives, presidential libraries, and government records recording the political history of the women's movement from the mid 1940's to the 1960's. Many of the documents accessed through the records of federal agencies may no longer be easily available to researchers, making Harrison's copies a potentially vital resource for historians. Harrison's notes and drafts synthesize and comment upon these primary sources, providing insight into the processes of drafting and publishing her book. Other materials highlight Harrison's personal commitment to the second-wave feminist movement, including letters of complaint to companies with sexist advertisements and business policies, and a collection of feminist publications that Harrison subscribed to.

Harrison's collection includes materials documenting the history of the Equal Rights Amendment and the Equal Pay Act, as well as the activities of the Presidential Commission on the Status of Women (PCSW) and the US Women's Bureau. Of particular interest are oral histories by PCSW members Esther Peterson (later director of the Women's Bureau) and Marguerite Rawalt. Other topics covered include the activities of local, grassroots feminist movements, women's reproductive rights and health education, sexism in American culture, and children's education and exposure to stereotyped gender roles.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Cynthia Ellen Harrison is a retired Associate Professor of History, Women's Studies, and Public Policy at The George Washington University. Since 1994 Professor Harrison served the University as a teacher and an active researcher in US women's political history. Harrison previously served as the Chief of the Federal Judicial History Office from 1988 to 1994, at the American Historical Association/American Political Science Association from 1982 to 1988, and as a research fellow at The Brookings Institute from 1979 to 1982. Harrison received her PhD in American History from Columbia University in 1982. From 1968 to 1972 Harrison worked as a librarian at first the Brooklyn Public Library, and later the McMaster University Library in Ontario, Canada.

Professor Harrison's publications include a large number of articles on the history of the US women's rights movement, two reference works on primary sources available to researchers in women's history, and a 1988 book, On Account of Sex: The Politics of Women's Issues, 1945 to 1968.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Professor Cynthia Ellen Harrison, 2014, (2014.022)

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into 12 series: Activism; Archival citations; Children's books; Equal pay; Equal Rights Amendment (ERA); Harrison's desk; Mailings, magazines, newsletters; Manuscript research; Oral history; Political involvement; Oversized boxes; and Women's issues resources

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

controlaccess.subject: Feminists
Women's rights
Feminist theory
Politics and culture -- United States -- 20th century

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains letters of complaint written by Cynthia Harrison to companies with sex discriminatory business practices or sexist advertisements. These letters, and replies from the companies, were sent largely during the mid-1970's and demonstrate Professor Harrison's personal commitment and activism in the women's rights movement.

did.unittitle: A. & S. (Abraham & Strauss) discriminatory alterations policy
First National Iron Bank discriminatory credit policy
Letter campaign against sexist ads & congratulatory letters to companies that portray women positively
Saks Fifth Avenue discriminatory credit policy
Washington Area Feminist Federal Credit Union

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of copy orders and citations from archives and libraries that Professor Harrison visited during the late 1970's in the process of collecting research material for her book. The list of archives and resources accessed by Harrison demonstrate her research process and provide insight into her writing.

Roosevelt, Eleanor I & II, Xerox order

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a selection of feminist children's books and publications documenting the pervasiveness of sexual stereotyping in mainstream children's literature. These publications date from the early to mid-1970's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photocopies of primary source material (reports, memoranda, drafts of bills, etc.), publications, and some of Harrison's personal notes on the history of the Equal Pay Act of 1963. The bulk of the material dates from the 1940's to the late 1960's. Much of the material orginated from the Women's Bureau.

did.unittitle: Equal Pay & Women in Labor Unions
EPA - History of the Bennett Amendment; correspondence & newsclips summer, 1965
EPA - Notebook material: "Equal Pay for Equal Work: Federal Legislature Activity 1945-1962" by J.P. Eavner December 14, 1962
Manual on Pay Equity: Raising Wages for Women's Work, conference on alternative state and local policies, Committee on Pay Equity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photocopies of primary source material (reports, memoranda, correspondence, etc.), and publications on the history of and debate surrounding the Equal Rights Amendment. The bulk of the material dates from the mid-1940's to the 1970's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, speech drafts, notes and collected articles and publicity releases for Harrison's "Women's Movement Media: A Source Guide." These materials were almost entirely produced by or for Professor Cynthia Harrison herself durin gthe 1970's and early 1980's.

did.unittitle: Coping with Conflict: Reproductive Choices and Community Controversy - brochure, League of Women Voters Education Fund

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photocopies of primary sources (reports, correspondence, publications, etc.) as well as other original primary source documentation used by Professor Harrison while researchign her 1988 book On Account of Sex: The Politics of Women's Issues, 1945-1968. Content relating to the Presdient's Commission on the Status of Women and the activities of the Women's Bureau are heavily represented, and span from the 1940's to the 1960's.

did.unittitle: Democratic National Committee (sources not used in manuscript)
National Women's Committee for Civil Rights

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of interview transcripts and oral histories from people active in the women's rights movement, including suffragist Alice Paul, Esther Peterson, Catherine East, Dr. Richard A. Lester, Edith Green, Marguerite Rawalt and Maurine Neuberger. Most of the interviews were conducted in the late 1970's to early 1980's.

did.unittitle: Interviews EG, EP, MN, RL, CE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of mailings from women political candidates and women's political organizations, party platform reports and analyses, and publications on women's rights legistlation dating largely from the 1980's and early 1990's. These documents are in part a collection of resources accumulated by Harrison, and in part evidence of Harrison's own participation in political activities.

did.unittitle: Center for American Woman and Politics Fact Sheets, Highlight Brochure, Press Advisory
Legislation Affecting the Status of Women
Position Paper draft: Women's Issues in the 1984 Campaign

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains oversized materials relating to the Equal Pay Act, Equal Rights Amendment, Title IX, and the women's rights movement in general dating from the 1940's to the 1980's.

did.unittitle: Esther Peterson Oral History John F. Kennedy Library
NYRF: New York Radical Feminists Newsletter
Women Returning to the Labor Force: A First Report, Women's Bureau Careers Centre Ontario Department of Labor

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains publications, newsletters, reports and mailings covering a wide range of women's rights issues and documenting the activities and concerns of feminist organizations in the late 1980's and early 1990's. Harrison's original organization scheme has largely been maintained, with folders on topics ranging from abortion, to work/family balance, to women in the media. Of particular interest are publications commenting on the UN Fourth World Conference on Women, and documents related to the formation in 2005 of GWU's Sexual Harassment Policy.
